author: @RobertRussell72001
text: The qubits are not in reverse. Think of a binary number: the right-most bit is the least significant and is considered the zeroth bit, and so on. Thus, in a, say, three bit number, the second bit is actually the left-most one, which is what you saw in the histogram.

author: @marc.lepage
text: Constructive YouTube comment: instead of spending several minutes throughout the video wondering which way the bits are ordered in the graph, it is much better to just pause recording, look it up, then resume recording. Or, if streaming, look it up live, then edit that part out in the final video. Because ultimately in the time spent pondering it, the answer could have been determined.

author: @ydb1976yt
text: OK, some insights: 1. the order of the bits in the x axis in the histogram, it makes some sense if you would think of it like we think of decimal numbers: if we have a column of numbers - we would align them so that the decimal points of all the numbers are aligned, if there is a number with more digits - those digits would stick out to the left (that would be the 3rd qubit) the digits we already use would be in the familiar (right side - close to the decimal point) places. 2. around the noise in the 38:00 - 3 qubits #2 rotated pi/4. found out that quickest way to cancel the noise (instead of 3qu/1c bits replay) is simply to remove the h(0) and h(1) - no noise... 3. so, the ratio for the #2 qubit was 0:~0.853 1:~0.147 surprised me, I was expecting 0:0.75 1:0.24 - then I checked something out - and it shows very good answer: if we look at the tip of the vector and project it (on the Z axis) it will be 1-cos(pi/4) under the top of the sphere if you take this and consider the "Z" as 2 (it is indeed 2 radii) - and we look at the proportion of what we got against 2 - it seems very similar to the result: (1-(cos(pi/4 rad)))/2=0.1464466094

text: IBM and others have dozens of qbits but these qbits are far from behaving perfectly. So even if 60 "perfect" qbits could be tremendously powerful, we're not there at all in 2020. Our current qbits are veeery far from perfect. So when you say it might happen in 1-2 years, well hold your horses, even 10 years is optimistic.

author: @lucanigro6773
text: every time the state vector ends up INSIDE the Bloch sphere its said to be in a MIXED STATE. Which is totally different from the quantum superposition: indeed whenever u got a PURE STATE (totally quantum mechanical superposition) the state vector points the surface of the Bloch sphere!   I'll try to explain the case in which  Hadamard applied to a qubit and then the cnot to the other one:  Hadamard takes a ket(0) pure state and gives a superposition of ket(0) and ket(1) with same amplitude. This is still a pure state. Than the cnot entangles the two qubits BUT unknowing the result of a measurement on the first qubit. And here comes the so called "statistically mixed" state: now there is 50%50% chance for both qubits of being on ket[0] or ket[1].   It's veryveryvery instructive to try and measure the first qubit BEFORE the cnot entanglement, this should give again a pure state. Analogous argument applies for the rest of the examples on the video. Love this channel!

author: @VincentBILLET26
text: Just shown your video to a friend... 27:10 : And I would like to explain WHY Qubits MUST be read from bottom to top. If you create a 3 Qubit circuit, with nothing on q0 and q1, and X on q2, then you will have 100% of chance to get |100> and 0% of chance to get |001>... WHY ? the reason is simple : put the following : 0x2^0 (q0) + 0x2^1 (q1) + 1x2^2 (q2) = 4 = 100b... So 100% on |100>... I know it's a bit confusing at the beginning, but you must read Qubits from bottom to top. So in you example : |000>, |001>, |010> and |111> are the good final states. Addditionnaly, there is something interesting with this circuit you don't show in your video : all the 4 phases are equals to 0, which is really usefull.

author: @biswanathbasak9843
text: Qiskit has the zeroth qubit at the right most digit, and the other qubits follow leftwards as mentioned in documentation, unlike a python list where the zeroth index is at the leftmost. The essence is similar to the construction of binary numbers, which totally makes sense since every qubit is intended to be "entangled" with others (unlike arrays/lists).

author: @ColinBroderickMaths
text: The reason the two qubits don't have state at 22:35 ish is because they're entangled. Entanglement literally means that the constituent systems don't have independent states, they only have their shared state, which can't be represented on the Bloch sphere (since it's for 1-qubit systems). There are ways you can sort of consider them to have independent state, but it's much more complicated.  Hadamard is a rotation just like all other fundamental quantum logic gates, it's just not around one of the main axes so it's a bit hard to interpret on the Bloch sphere. All fundamental quantum logic gates are unitary which for these purposes is the same as being a rotation (but that rotation may be in a complex many-dimensional space). It's also not just for putting things into superposition, but taking them out as well. It you apply it twice you'll get out of superposition.  At 22:43 onwards I think some of the confusion comes from the fact that you've entangled qubit 2 with the combination of qubits 0 and 1, but qubits 0 and 1 are not actually entangled with each other. So e.g. measuring only qubit 0 does not impact qubit 1, and gives you partial information on qubit 2. I think you're right about the bit ordering though. Qubit states are normally written in a big-endian way, so qubit 0 would be in the last position. This is no different to regular binary numbers in computer science where bit 0 is the least significant bit. This is potentially confusing if you're not often operating at the level of bits.  Some of the confusing directionality on the Bloch sphere is due to the fact that state vector amplitudes are complex numbers. You square (more accurately, multiply the number by it's complex conjugate) these amplitudes to get probabilities and this squaring is why different-looking complex vectors give the same output. States are generally normalized since certain operations only make sense in that case, which is why your partially entangled vectors from the previous paragraph didn't have unit length: their state was only (fully) defined in the 3-qubit space and that is the space in which they must be normalized.  I wouldn't suggest you actually do anything like this by hand, but any missing 1- or 2-qubit gates/operations are just the matrix products of existing 1- and 2-qubit operations, and higher-dimensional gates are the Kronecker product of those operations to give higher-dimensional operators. So any combination does exist if you can write it in a mathematically consistent way. Building it into a real machine is another story of course!  My master's thesis is in quantum computation and I currently work as a machine learning software developer, so it looks like our interests overlap quite a bit.  My master's was in mathematical physics rather than computer science or engineering. I'd be happy to talk to you more about qc if you're interested. Full disclosure: it has been a while so I'm rusty.

author: @michael-nef
text: At 28:00 you say that you think the bit values are around the wrong way. I think you're correct because: You have 8 "possible" final measurements:  000, 001, 010, 011, 100, 101, 110, 111  we know that if the final bit is flipped (the one you apply X to), then the conditional bits MUST both be measured as 1 (because it's if(qubit1 && qubit2): X(qubit3)) so our new "logically possible" measurements are: 000, ---, 010, ---, 100, ---, ---, 111  notice 001 is not a possible measurement, which is shown on the graph.  Also, I could absolutely be wrong, but I think the final distribution of probabilities would still be 1/4 each. because there's a 1/2 chance of qubit1 being a 1 or 0, and there's a 1/2 chance of qubit2 being 1 or 0. So,  00_ will happen 1/4 of the time, 01_ will happen 1/4 of the time, 10_ will happen 1/4 of the time and 11_ will happen 1/4 of the time. Given that, it's pretty straightforward to see that qubit3's measured value will be totally dependent on the values of qubit1 and qubit2 and you can fill in the "_"'s by hand.
